DOC.HEAD: Prices Mixed
DOC.TEXT: The energy futures market ended mixed in volatile trading Wednesday, erasing much of its earlier gains that stemmed from news of a sudden U.S. military strike in Panama. Prices for crude and refined petroleum products had been up sharply earlier in the trading day Wednesday on fears that the closure of the Panama Canal, following the surprise attack by American forces, might disrupt oil shipments. But analysts said the market had over-reacted. ``I think the reaction to the Panama closure was totally irrational,'' Bob Baker, an energy analyst with Prudential-Bache, said. ``Our crude oil supplies simply won't be disrupted.'' Analysts said that only a small percentage of crude shipped to the United States passes through the Panama Canal because the waterway is too small to handle large tankers. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the February contract for West Texas Intermediate, the leading grade of U.S. crude oil, was down 7 cents to settle at $21.21 per 42-gallon barrel. The contract was up 11 cents on Tuesday. Among refined petroleum products, the January wholesale home heating oil contract, supported in recent days from a cold spell that hit parts of the nation, rose 0.75 cent to settle at 75.76 cents a gallon. On Tuesday, the contract gained 0.35 cent. January wholesale unleaded gasoline, which lost 0.58 cent in the previous session, ended 0.71 cent lower to 53.22 cents a gallon.
